eY_zvstI6tBvkaVnS4-IYw.text: There were things I loved about this place and things I hated. Settled on 2 stars because if I'm spending $1300 on dinner for 2, it should have been the best meal of my life.  Pros: The restaurant is beautiful and the staff are pleasant and always at your service.  The bread cart and the dessert cart had over 15 variations of each and they were all delicious. By far the best part of the meal.  Cons: We got the 15 course tasting menu and a bottle of wine. We are both good eaters and like almost anything and there were some things I just ate because I couldn't fathom leaving on my plate because of how much money I was spending.   I guess I went in with high expectations given the price tag and was disappointed!

photos.caption: Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States

SGSM_FYNjscYGzfIE4p1Vg.text: My husband and I came to experience Joel Robouchon for our birthday celebrations. We made reservation for 8:30 pm on Monday night.  We were seated promptly by the hostess   I ordered from the $198 four course menu (which includes amuse bouche, 2 appetizers, one entree, one dessert, and sweets) My husband ordered from the $169 two course menu (which includes amuse bouche, 1 appetizer, one entree, and sweets)  The service was good, but not impeccable We declined the wine, and had bottle of sparkling water for $10  The bread cart came out first, variety of artisan breads, my husbands favorite was the bacon bread and I like the flaky white puff pastry. fine butter and olive oil was provided They will bring more bread upon request at no additional charge  The amuse bouche was a beet puree, it was creamy with twist of citrus, very refreshing  The appetizers My husband ordered imperial caviar on king crab in crustacean gelee at a $65 supplement, this dish was divine the caviar was light, yet each bead was bursting with flavor...one can taste the essence of the ocean with each savory dollop. the king crab enhances the flavor of the caviar nicely the crustacean gelee does not overpower  My first appetizer was the spiced lobster in Daikon cream the lobster was chilled and very well prepared The second appetizer was the foie gras salad with artichoke the cold preparation of the foie gras is not our favorite but the richness of the foie gras was sublime  Entree My husband ordered the farm chicken with foie gras and roasted chestnuts with black truffles at $40 supplement. My husband throughly enjoyed his dish. the chicken is perfectly cooked and the foie gras was seared to perfection and melted in the mouth.   I ordered the sea bass. I was a little disappointed by this dish. I feel the sea bass was a little over cooked and bit on the salty side.  Dessert We shared the chocolate souffle at $15 supplement it came with dark chocolate ice cream (almost ganache like) and vanilla bean ice cream. sumptuous   the sweets cart came last too many variety to count we tried all the macaroons, including apple, hazelnut, pistachio; and loved all of them of note, the available baklava, creme brulee, and panna cotta was available to order from the kitchen We each had the creme brulee, this was delicious to the nth degree  take home message, save the money that you would otherwise gamble away at the casino to eat here  (This entry was written by my husband)

photos.caption: Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Farm chicken and foie gras with roasted chestnuts and black truffles
Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beet puree amuse bouche
Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Assortment of breads

uEx8wQDx0KhopUMr2P_Qug.text: What an experience!  Many many reviews that give details on the food so I will focus on my experience.  This was our first Michellin experience and it lived up to the hype. Their service was excellent and our group of 5 were treated like royalties in probably the most beautiful restaurant I've ever been in.  It was pricey, we did the tasting menu. It was delicious and well worth it. We also did the wine pairings which I would probably wouldn't do again. A great sommelier could likely provide excellent recommendations for better value. We always tend to do the wine pairings with a tasting menu and this was the first time we weren't blown away.   Would highly recommend for a special occasion or celebration. It truly is an experience!

Oh0gIRVmhMiIIP_gBKOMww.text: This being our first (and much anticipated) visit, we wanted to get the full experience, so we opted for the 16 course tasting menu for around $400 per person.  We also got a wine pairing, which is priced in tiers (around $250, $500, and $1000 per person, I believe).  We opted for the middle tier and the wines were outstanding, I can't even imagine what the top tier must be like!  Le Pain (the bread) - this is not your ordinary bread selection.  There are at least 15 types of bread offered including baguettes, puff pastry, basil or saffron brioche, and much more.  When you have made your (unlimited) selections, the servers warm them for you then shave a piece of butter off of a huge block (that gets its own cart) and sprinkle it with sea salt for you.  I could make a whole meal out of this bread cart, no joke.  La Cerise (the cherry) - cherry gazpacho with sheep ricotta ans pistachios.  Light and refreshing.  La Tomate (the tomato) - salad of tomato with basil infused olive oil, tomato gelee topped with mozzarella.  We were instructed to place the tomato onto the gelee and eat them together.  A deconstructed caprese salad - this was interesting and tasty.  Le Caviar - three courses served at once - red turnip and butter coated radish with yellowtail carpaccio and caviar, chilled cauliflower veloute with bonito gelee and caviar, caviar and couscous maki roll.  This was one of the standout courses of the evening (how could it not be?), especially the carpaccio.  La Grenouille (the frog) - crispy frog leg, roasted garlic, parsley coulis.  Very meaty and succulent - this was one of my favorites.  La Saint-Jacques (name of a traditional French scallop dish) - seared scallop in a cauliflower veloute for me and a green curry for DH.  At the beginning of the meal, they ask for food allergies/preferences.  I specified "no cilantro", so they made a substitution for me.  They are very gracious and courteous about this.  Les Crustaces (the crustaceans) - three courses served at once - truffled langoustine ravioli with foie gras foam, sea urchin on potato puree with coffee, grilled spiny lobster medallion with herb sabayon.  This was one of the best courses, if not THE best, of the evening (especially the ravioli, which is one of their signature dishes).  Les Petit Pois (the little peas) - delicate green pea cream on top of foie gras with argan oil.  I enjoyed this much more than the earlier cherry soup.  Le Saumon (the salmon) - a perfectly medium salmon filet with grain mustard and mango "tagliatelle".  Another of my favorites.  Le Boeuf (the beef) - pepper crusted rib eye with capers, peppers, and mushrooms.  I was so full at this point that I could not eat more than a bite of this, but DH loved it.  Le Soja (the soybean) - soy risotto with lime and chives.  We were both too full to eat much of this.  La Fraise (the strawberry) - a caramel panna cotta with fresh strawberries, balsamic reduction, and creme fraiche foam.  Kind of like a deconstructed strawberry shortcake.  I don't know if it was because the end was in sight, or the change from savory to sweet - but we were both able to recover a little bit and finish these last 2 courses.  Le Citron (the lemon) - honey gelee and a light lemon cream finished with a spiced red fruit coulis, yum.  Le Moka, Les Mignardises (the coffee, the small desserts) - Lastly, we were presented with this beautiful cart from which we could take whatever we wanted.  Stuffed to the brim, but a wonderful and beautiful experience!  I would love to return, but considering how full we got and how sick I was that night because of it, I would order differently.  The 16 course is a wonderful way to experience all that they have to offer, but it is just too much (especially with the wine pairing).  Next time, I will order the 6 course menu where I can choose my favorite dishes and still take advantage of the marvelous bread and petit fours cart.  The 6 course menu also includes the cheese cart which the 16 course did not (which made me sad, but there was no way that I would have had room for it anyway).  I have also heard that you can split 1 wine pairing between 2 people, which would be a much more reasonable amount than what we had.

qp66wz_FsRXNhNzsSSEsOA.text: Had the pleasure to dine here this week to celebrate a birthday. Oh, what an amazing experience!  ATMOSPHERE: It may be located next to Ka and right off the casino floor, but it feels like a world away. Masterful soundproofing and design transports you to someplace quiet and elegant.   FOOD: We opted for the 5-course tasting menu. Every single thing we enjoyed was amazingly prepared and thoughtfully presented. No surprise there, given the culinary chops of the restaurant's namesake and the talented team he created. But, what was surprising were the special little touches - the stuff-of-dreams bread cart, the whimsical selections of tiny desserts.   DRINKS: Also no surprise here - the wine and beverage list offer many fantastic choices. I opted for a French 75 and a half bottle of excellent white wine. (My companion doesn't drink, so I was pleased to have that option.) You will not go thirsty here.  SERVICE: Everyone there made you feel like an honored guest. They also celebrated my husband's birthday in such a lovely way. Service was exceptionally attentive without being cloying. We kept thanking them profusely for everything because we were so thrilled.   I can not wait to return next time we visit.

tBMK5_8fBNSB13n9qlxgyg.text: Sooo here's the thing. This place deserves 5 starts, the experience is amazing. Of course service was amazing all the choices of bread, fancy butter... all the stuff that makes it sooooo expensive. Me and my girlfriend both did the 17 course meal, and we personally were not a fan of the food. Now I'm not saying the food was bad, but not the food I would personally order. Overall amazing experience, and that's the reason I paid for it. It takes a few hours for the course meal, FYI.

RKj_z-HzeVy6r6TW69Y72A.text: Joel Robuchon is in a class by itself and is a True rarity. I can guarantee that you have never been to a legitimately fine restaurant in your life unless you have been here or to one of few in the world that are on par with Joel Robuchon.  I knew that a truly elegant restaurant must exist somewhere in the USA and I finally found it.  The decor and staff of Joel Robuchon is unparalleled and rivals no other in my vast experience. Immaculate-condition interior and quality taste meets with beautiful and cohesive ambience. Eye-catching serviceware is put into action such as the bread cart featuring many fresh varities with house-made butter underglass.   Food is sophisticated and beyond exceptional. All is unique and prepared perfectly. Artistic presentation and attention to detail of cuisine is like no other.  The music selections were wonderful. Brahms piano concertos and the like make for a serene atmoshphere.  Our group had the 17-course menu which is far too extravagant and complex to describe in this review but suffice to say was well worth 445 dollars per person (wine not included) and I highly recommend this menu for a five-hour dining experience. Every course was a surprise in tastes, colors, and textures and visually stunning. The dessert cart was extraordinary featuring dozens of classics as well as unique creations.   The wait service was impeccably dressed and genuinely formal with each course being explained to its finest points.   In conclusion and to provide contrast, it is important to note that much of what makes Joel Robuchon exceptional is that it is devoid of all errors characteristic of virtually all other so-called upscale restaurants. Best to list some of these ubiquitous errors. Joel Robuchon suffers from none of these flaws:  1. Decor/furnishings that are bric-a-brac and/or damaged. 2. Eye-sores like plastic dish buckets and cleaning supplies visible. 3. Food/dirty remnants stuck on walls and furniture and stains all about. 4. Clanking of dishes from busboys and general cacophony.  5. Precooked "lazy" foods/glorified leftovers that are made in bulk. 6. Limited ingredients used in permutations for all entrees/apps. 7. Money/labor-saving techniques. 8. Inappropriate/plebeian music. 9. Casual behavior and mannerisms of staff. 10. Boorish diners. 11. Restaurant-supply store goods. 12. Poorly selected/unripe fruit and vegetable parts. 13. Hurried food preparation. 14. Inept service. 15. Dirty/worn menus. 16. Trending menu items.  Like many of us, we have all been to many so-called upscale restaurants but these are flawed in most every respect. I have been long privy to so-called upscale restaurants that are essentially uncaringly run and are cost-cutting, poorly maintained/unclean and riddled with service/etiquette errors not to mention mediocre food quality.   Lastly, I would like to thank Joel Robuchon staff and its superb effort for finally meeting my expectations of a True fine-dining experience that will be remembered for a lifetime.  Far more than five-star rating is merited.

HifS5otboewx5dsjTfs8Gw.text: I have never been as impressed with service and food as I am with Joel Robuchon. Then again, this is why it ranks in the top 10 restaurants in the world.  I unfortunately do not have a very discerning palate.  I wish i do.  All I know is when I like a dish, I like it.  If not, then no.  With that said, lemme emphasize:  every single thing that came out of the kitchen was mind blowing.  Presentation, flavor, service.  I've been hard pressed to find another restaurant that would top Joel Robuchon, even here in Los Angeles where we have a myriad of places to choose from.  Definitely go for the Tribute and/or Experience Menu.  Go with someone so you get to try both.  Coz YOLO.

oh80_YpGqdu73KzOCqCRhw.text: I made a reservation about 2 weeks in advance to celebrate my birthday with my SO and had extremely high expectations mainly because this restaurant is often described as the epitome of fine dining experiences not only in LV, but arguably in the nation as well.   I'll start off by saying that I've been to two other restaurants by Joel Robuchon and like many others fell in LOVE with his food. First experience being the next door L'Atelier By Joel Robuchon (it's literally next door) and another in Japan. Both were excellent and gave me more reasons to be excited to finally engage in this ultimate fine dining experience!   Service  Must start here because service is simply the best. Despite the restaurant being very high end, the staff were very very friendly and the service feels very personalized. I am especially impressed with the service because we were unable to finish the degustation menu that we got (16-course meal spread out to 6 big courses comprised of various delicacies) and had to give up with our last course remaining (excluding dessert). We just had one too many drinks beforehand :(.  The staff were very understanding of this and even offered to provide a small discount for the last dish we couldn't get to. I thought their response to our disappointing performance was very nice.   Food  Three highlights for me -  bread, Le caviar imperial, and the desserts! With Joel Robuchon's restaurants every plate is a work of art. He'll even make questionable ingredients like frog legs to make it look like a fine piece of art that even tastes good. I'll break down all three of my highlights a bit. This, by the way, isn't to say that all the rest of the course wasn't impressive. I really liked the tomato in the first course, the sea urchin (uni) was freaking fresh... I can go on and on, so you've just got to try it!  Bread- i pretty much spent the whole night wondering how their bread remains so freaking soft and chewy (not the hard, oh I'm going to break my teeth chewy) when they're out in the open the whole time? It really is a shame that you'll probably only be able to try 3-4 pieces at most and the olive oil they serve is just mind blowing!!!!   Le caviar imperial- I LOVE caviar. If I see it on the menu, I'll order it even though I don't like it when it gets served on food as a topping and sometimes those caviars can have very strong odor and be extremely salty. But this dish makes you feel like you're a small fish swimming happily in the Pacific Ocean with a big grin on your face cause you're finally home (if you know what I mean). The presentation of this dish just completes it!! It's covered in jelly-ish thing and I think that really offsets the salty taste if you take in too much caviar at once like a palate cleaner.  Anyway, it's just perfect and there's a reason why this is one of the most famous dishes he was known for.   Desserts- so we gave up on the last course of our 6-course degustation, but we couldn't give up on the dessert. Desserts here is just out of this world. It looks amazing and it tastes even better than it looks (and that's really hard to do). I am oh so very happy about the pound cake and the macaroons they give you as a parting gift cause I'm devouring that as soon as I get home!!!!   Their complimentary bday cake also puts this restaurant in its own league. First, it's an ice cream cake with meringue. When's the last time you had an ice cream cake??? I haven't had one esp for my bday since I was 11. Second, that presentation!! I honestly felt like a royalty. You'll have to see the pix.   PRICE- yes, at $445/pp, you'll easily rack up over $1K for 2 people on the bill. Corkage is $50 (some reviews here says $100, I'm guessing it went down since), so BYO if you plan on drinking (if you order a glass, you'll most likely be paying 45+). Overall, the experience is totally worth it!! I hope to go back :)

Y99kbvA51jd2LTMNjIlrSg.text: The epitome of French fine dining, and exactly what a 3 Michelin Star meal should be. Located within the MGM Grand, the interior is a tranquil, luxurious escape from hectic Las Vegas. Ornate chandeliers, saturated jewel tones, and plush velvet seating create an ambience of timeless elegance. There was even a stool for my purse. Reservations were easy to acquire 2 weeks in advance. Management will reach out to you 3 days prior to your meal to confirm, and note any special requests.  My boyfriend and I came here with friends who are strict vegans, and the staff were incredibly accommodating. Their meal was just as special as ours, with equal substitutes for every course. The menu lists 4 different options to create your own menu, but honestly, you are doing yourself a disservice by not enjoying the full Menu Degustation ($450 per person, or $375 for the vegetarian version). These consist of 17 small dishes, presented over the course of about 3 hours.   From the amuse bouche to the concluding confections, everything we consumed was astoundingly good. I was in awe of the bread cart, from which I enjoyed saffron brioche, fluffy milk bread, a gruyere puff, and even a mini croissant with their salted, creamy imported French butter. My favorite dish overall was the Green Asparagus Veloute on scallion jam with ricotta tortellini pasta. The rich, vegetable spiced sauce enrobed every bite of the delicate, pillowy pasta, leaving lingering earthy undertones on the palate.   The dessert courses were as beautiful as they were delicious, and varied with one fruit-forward course (served atop a sake gelee!) and then a chocolate/coffee fondant. Just when I thought I could not possibly eat anything else, the dessert cart arrived, whimsically displaying dozens of bite sized treats-truffles, canele, macarons, and petit fours galore. Somehow, I managed to sample 8 selections.   Service was polished and professional, with a genuine tact that was much appreciated by myself and company. At the conclusion of the meal, we were gifted a lemon pound cake to take home, which we enjoyed with coffee all week. Like everything at Joel Robuchon, it was perfection, and kept the dining experience fresh in our thoughts. This ranks among the best meals of my life, and I look forward to returning.

cI07q8kiyZdShC97-2wotA.text: My brother Andrew C. turned 30 last month, and to celebrate, Matt B. and I treated him and Celestine H. to a blowout dinner at Joel Robuchon. I was able to book a 10:00 Saturday night table just over a week in advance. I requested an earlier time if possible and was pleased when a 9:00 seating opened up the day of our reservation.  The restaurant was beautiful, so sumptuous and peaceful, it was almost hard to believe the MGM casino was right outside the door. We dressed up, adhering to the dress code (there was one man in the dining room dressed in shorts, and he looked like an asshole). Joel Robuchon was fancy, and the extravagant grandeur was a lot of the fun.  Service was impeccable, attentive and delightfully formal, with staff in spotless uniforms lifting cloches from elegant plates. There was a whole team of people taking care of us, and they were all polite and mega-competent. I don't think we ever needed to ask for anything, except for a few photos at the end of the meal.  We were seated right when we arrived, then presented with menus and a welcome bite. We enjoyed tiny, crispy quinoa croquettes as we pondered our options, ordering a round of cocktails before deciding on food and wine. These were unnecessary--$22 a pop for mostly standard nice cocktails--but definitely enjoyable. I got the Mr. Robuchon Gin & Tonic, and this was easily the best one, a refreshing G & T with house-infused Botanist dry gin, Fever Tree tonic, and Scrappy's lime bitters. The others were good, too. The Corpse Reviver No. 2 was made with Monkey 47 gin, Cointreau, Lillet Blanc, lemon juice, and absinthe drop; the Hemingway Papa Doble with Diplomatico Planas rum, Luxardo Maraschino, grapefruit juice, and lime juice; the Ward Eight with Eagle Rare bourbon, lemon, grapefruit juice, and Jack Rudy grenadine.  Joel Robuchon offers a number of menu options, ranging from $127 for a main course and dessert with an amuse bouche and mignardises to $445 for an enormous tasting menu. We went for the $198 menu, which fell in the middle, with two appetizers on top of the entry-level selection. We also ordered a wine pairing--there were tiers here, too, and we picked the lowest one, which was still almost $200 a head. This was worth it, though, for a super special birthday dinner. The wines were great and the pours heavy, and the thoughtful pairings added a lot to the meal, and to its sense of occasion.  The food was exquisite. I couldn't believe that fucking bread cart. There were like twenty kinds of bread, and we could have any of them we wanted, with hand-churned Normandie butter and some terrific olive oil. I tried the mini-baguette, the saffron focaccia, the rosemary brioche, and breads with gruyere, bacon, comte, and milk. All superb.  The amuse bouche was a fantastic cherry tomato gazpacho, tangy and cool, with balsamic reduction, pistachio, and a dollop of ricotta sorbet. For my first appetizer, I got the Maine lobster, which came in little faux ravioli, sweet lobster meat tucked between thin slices of turnip, finished with radish and a sweet and sour dressing. Next, I had the green asparagus veloute, a delicious silky green soup poured over peas, ricotta tortellini, and scallion jam. I also sneaked a bite of Matt's seared duck foie gras with confit peppers and acidic tomato glaze, which cost an extra $25. It was, of course, excellent.  Matt and I shared our entrees, and there was a clear winner here. The black cod was amazing, caramelized and buttery, served on a black garlic puree with shiso and lemongrass emulsion. The grilled beef ribeye, though, was surprisingly mediocre, definitely the weakest dish of the night. It just wasn't very tender or flavorful, though I liked the crispy gyoza of foie gras and celeriac accompaniments.  We shared all our desserts and made one of them a cheese plate, mostly because we saw the cheese cart going around (maybe this makes us simple, but we were very impressed with all the carts). There were a dozen cheeses on that thing, and we asked for a varied selection. We got the Brillat-Savarin, the Pont l'Eveque, the comte, the Crottin de Chavignol, and the Roquefort, and they were all lovely.  Then we had lots of sugar. The bitter chocolate souffle was the highlight here, airy and warm, served with vanilla ice cream. I also enjoyed La Sphere, a gorgeous sugar bubble filled with blueberry yogurt sorbet, candied lemon, and violet cream. Le Papillon Chocolat Azelia was a sweet terrarium of hazelnut milk chocolate cremeux with coffee chantilly and praline ice cream.  Dinner ended with one last cart, exploding with mignardises. I tried a pineapple coconut lollipop, a chocolate-covered orange peel, a strawberry tart, a raspberry tart, a banana eclair, a religieuse eclair, a canele, a kaffir lime chocolate, and a panna cotta, all tiny, sweet delights. As a parting gift, we received whole loaves of lemon pound cake. This was wonderful and over the top, a fitting way to end this phenomenal, decadent meal.

SiJz96nSuzcXQ6m9Zi2P-A.text: Of course I'd give it five stars. What else could you give it?? I was sad we didn't make it before Robuchon's passing.  We made the reservation several months in advance. When we got there, it was very quiet. Luckily, a few more parties showed up and it got a bit louder. We did the 17 course menu, and were not disappointed. I won't go into each detail but I am still dreaming about the Osetra Caviar and King Crab stack, the bread and dessert cart. The wine was decadent. It was truly a once in a lifetime experience.

EH6jLsjN9PD1DEzbRaHb7g.text: I have always wanted to try Joel Robuchon because it's one of those restaurants that had gotten a 3 Michelin Stars. So, my fiancee surprised me for our anniversary dinner.   I don't believe JR has the 3 Michelin stars anymore, so don't get your expectation hyped up. The food here is great, but it's not like blown my mind away great. Maybe it's just the fact that I'm not a French food type of girl. The bread here though, I gotta tell ya, it's from another world. If you love bread or even if you don't (I normally don't eat bread), make sure you try as many pieces at you can.   They do give you a selection of 2, 3 or 4 course meal with or without the petite desserts. If I were to do it all over again, I would choose the 3 course meal (including the dessert) instead of the 4 course meal.  Another reason you don't want to choose too many courses (or one without the dessert) is that their dessert is the bomb!  You can actually choose "all" of the petite dessert and they'll course it out for you. Boy, I wish I had the stomach to do that.   Oh, don't forget to try their butter that is imported from France. It's one of the richest, fattiest and most flavorful butter I've ever tasted (and I'm not a butter person).  The olive oil they have is also out of this world.  I was actually told you can buy a bottle from Amazon, which my fiancee did right away.    Tip: Make reservation early if you can; otherwise, you'll get a late night seating, which will ruin your stomach for the desserts.

qFIFxnMX_fG5S-T_5EDGMg.text: Eating at Joel Robuchon was truly and experience. Each and every dish prepared was absolutely amazing, cooked to perfection. Most courses were served with up to three dishes on the plate, most of which were tasting dishes: one to two bites each. The flow of the meal was slightly problematic though. At the beginning of the meal, we ended up  waiting around twenty minutes for the first couple of courses, which personally, felt too long. However the sequence of dishes was perfect. At the end of the meal I didn't feel stuffed, but full enough, not needing to eat more. The food was rich, but not too rich. The service was generally very good, keeping water filled at the beginning of service, although towards the middle and end of service, they struggled to keep glasses full. If this was some ordinary restaurant it would've had 5 stars, but for its price and status, I thought it could've been a little bit better.

-84ccK4trBHSSLIojN9jEA.text: I have mixed feelings about Joel Robuchon... I am VERY torn between giving this a four star or a five star. Most of my complaints are a bit nit picky at this point. So, first off, the atmosphere was wonderful. Inside is beautiful and My boyfriend and I got to sit in a little indoor area that was made to look like an outdoor patio. My boyfriend and I opted for the 17 or 18 course tasting menu since we rarely come to Vegas.   Right off the bat, we were served bread from an amazing bread cart. Words cannot describe how AMAZING the bread it. I honestly could just eat the breads for a meal. I got very basic breads (baby baguette, baby croissant, and baby milk bread) and they were great. My boyfriend got more adventurous breads (like the saffron bread) and he loved it too. Now, onto the dishes. The dishes were amazingly creative. Much more creative than most Michelin restaurants in the Bay Area. There was a tomato with gazpacho IN THE tomato... also the tomato was so fresh like summertime... taste like those farmer's market tomato and not the supermarket ones. There was also a corn soup with marshmallow that was very memorable. The ribeye there was also one of the best I ever had. It had the flavor of ribeye but the texture of a filet minion. I will say that they give you TONS of food when you order the full blown tasting menu.   The reason why I am a bit torn about the restaurant is because there were certain dishes that I did not feel were balanced.  There was this asparagus soup that was so delicious but had little bits of orange peel that were very bitter. The uni also tasted over seasoned and not clean and fresh. I prefer everything to be well balanced.  I know my boyfriend thought I was being nit picky.  Also, the service was a bit cold and not memorable. Comparing this place with Guy Savoy (which was much cheaper and probably almost as good if not just as good) I would choose Guy Savoy.   Nevertheless, I still give this place 5 stars because, in the end, it is very innovative and the experience was great. If you have the money to spend I would definitely say try this place. I plan to try all the other Joel Robuchons around the world!

HOvfV9zqNEfw8q25gbhc-g.text: Joel Robuchon is definitely a must try! There are only two seating times 5:30 PM and 8:30 PM. I suggest making reservations in case. They won't seat you until it's actually the time of the reservation.  The service was superb and just as we expected. Kit and Anthony were very accommodating. There are several menus to choose from. We tried the 5-course menu which is $250 per person. It comes with two appetizers, two entrees, and one dessert, which I think is more than enough food. I was getting full once I got my first entree. For starters, you also get a variety of unlimited bread, which, although yummy, I recommend you don't eat much of. My favorites were the L'uf de Poule Miroir (egg on top of hash brown with Ibarra bacon and truffle) and the Le Buf (two small pieces of ribeye with two pieces of macaroni filled meat).  Can't wait to go back and try the rest!

kIpkeWCo-WxsqpeVmzoU7g.text: My girlfriend and I decided to visit Las Vegas for our 1 week vacation and I decided to take her here for her Birthday.  This is our first 3 Michelin Star Restaurant and it was definitely worth it.    Service: The receptionist checked our coats in and the waiter takes us to our seat.   The waiters were very professional, explained every dish we ordered, and they serve us bread from the bread cart.  They even scooped the butter I accidentally dropped on the table.    Food: There are different price ranges when ordering a 3 course meal.  We went with 2 menu A which cost $250 each.  This comes with 2 appetizers, 2 entrees, and 1 dessert.  There are some dishes that will cost extra, but it is totally worth it in my opinion.  The bread cart and the dessert cart are complimentary that makes the experience even better.    Overall: This is definitely an amazing experience.  It is definitely pretty pricey, however it is something I feel everyone should try!

photos.caption: Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_JezjbzYnWujxG7KAoCpiw.text: What an experience!  This is by far the most expensive meal I've had but it was worth every penny.  The attention to detail in every presentation/interaction with the staff was amazing.    There are a few different tasting menus to try.  Basically you can choose how many courses you'd like.  Then, from an adjacent list, you choose which apps, entrees and deserts you'd like.  Some choices come with a "supplement" meaning add on $XX.xx amount of money depending on the dish.  I opted for the $198 menu which came with 2 appetizers, a main course, a desert and a sweet.   For my two appetizers I chose the lobster and asparagus soup.  One word: perfect.  So much flavor packed into such a tiny portion.  It was unbelievable.  For my entree I chose the veal stuffed with ham and cheese.  Again, perfect.  The server added a small helping of mashed potatoes to each of our dishes.  I have NEVER had mashed potatoes whipped so finely.  The texture was insane (in a good way).   Now desert was a spectacle in it's own right.  I chose the chocolate souffle which came with a $10 supplement.  So worth it!  Tbh, not very flattering in pics like most of their deserts, but what it lacked in visual appeal it made up for in flavor.  Wow!  Once desert was finished, they brought around a desert cart with small bite sized tarts, truffles and macarons.  So yummy!  Once we finished those, they brought around ANOTHER sweet.  This was a combination of a mini creme brulee and a blackberry ricotta yogurt thing?  So amazing.   This is an experience!  This is something everyone should do at least once.  Thank you for a perfect dinner, I'll be talking about this place for the rest of my life.

wnT7_8yW6BKd44HEUiJJZA.text: My boyfriend took me here for my birthday on January 2, and it was amazing! The only 3 Michelin Star restaurant in Las Vegas! *** Locals   Mostly tourists come, but there is only ONE 3 Michelin Star restaurant in Las Vegas! *** Travelers  Joel Robuchon is famous for having many Michelin stars. He is famous for his restaurants. Definitely make a reservation and make your way to these restaurants when traveling to Las Vegas in advance! *** My Recommendation  We got the set menus where we had 2 appetizers, 2 entrees and 1 dessert. I came with my boyfriend and we made sure to get different dishes to taste everything to share. Their bread and dessert cart are out of this world! You will definitely be full with those carts. Service is amazing! Be careful not to be mistaken with L'Atelier by Joel Robuchen as well which is right next door!  IG: @foodisseur

_3Vho_xv6Ko7Iu7xuJznsg.text: Dining here was a real treat.  My father treated my mom and I to a meal here as our final stop on our vacation. We were seated in a nice table and were given kind assistance from the waiters. we ordered the 18-Course Tasting Menu at Joel Robuchon. I was not eating food, I was eating art. Each piece was carefully planned and crafted with the most fresh ingredients from the best sources around the world. All the seafood and meats were so smooth and perfectly cooked, the veggies were properly sauteed, and the sauces were perfectly painted on the plates. I do not have a favorite because each were so different, delicious and balanced.

DZC914Bj9ikuRRvk7PGiwQ.text: Classic, quiet, great ambiance and comfortable. Everything I had here was great. This place is a must try...at least once. Breads are good...that butter is amazing. Food has wonderful presentation...but if I could give you one tip. Say no to the champagne in the beginning...it $50 a glass. Pretty much pissed me off when I got the bill. We paid $200 for 4 glasses. Should have bought a bottle instead.   Also I've tried both restaurants. Next door has a better vibe and IMO the food is tastier.

ycOyr5V9uMWcLNEZ0297Gw.text: The billing as a 3-star Michelin restaurant is definitely warranted. It has all the bells and whistles that any other 3-star restaurant has including atmosphere, menu, and service. The location doesn't fit the expectation of a restaurant of this ilk as it sits within the aging MGM Grant Hotel & Casino. That said, once you enter the restaurant itself, the transformation into a decadent location happens. The service we experienced was superb from the hostess to the Maitre D was very nice. The room was light and airy and surprising was half empty on a late Friday night. Both the menu and wine listing were extensive and offered something for everyone. But anyone booking a reservation here shouldn't expect sticker shock at $1,000 bottles of wine and $22-$75 glasses of wine. The menu as to be expected at most french 2 and 3 Michelin star restaurants indeed pricey and offered both tasting menu's in 4, 5, 6 and even 15-course offerings. I wanted to try the 15 courses but we had a show in 2 hours and felt the time was against me. Instead, we tried the 5-coursee menu. The courses, in short, were spectacular. At this price point your expecting that, but the food was beyond the beyond. The first course was a corn-based gazpacho with tiny bits of prosciutto and cream. It tasted like heaven in a bowl. Soft, creamy and with a balance of salt made you instantly want more. And in True French fashion, they serve just enough for you to understand what your tasting, but not enough that you don't want more.  The bread cart that followed the 1st course was something out of a bakery. A cart filled with at least 10 different types of fresh-baked bread. The star we tasted was a buttered bread that tasted warm and chewy with no need for butter or olive oil. Speaking of which, the waiter paired the cart of pieces of bread with a separate tray of carved butter from a tower of house-made butter that looked amazing.  The next few courses were also as good as the first. foie gras pan-seared with artichoke and pistachio cream. One of the other standouts was the Wahoo fish dish that sort of melted in your mouth. The dish didn't disappoint from the waiter's high recommendation. The dessert tray was amazing even for a french restaurant so many choices but let me end this review with this. We ordered the chocolate souffle. Of course it was homemade and of course, it was the best thing I have ever tasted for dessert, like ever. It came with two different sauces to choose from. I don't remember the sauces as they were an afterthought of the souffle. The Chef came out to say hi, which is always nice. But as a foodie, I wanted to marry him and divorce my wife for guaranteed meals like this for the rest of my life ;).  Adventures and meals like this are truly once in a lifetime. For me the experience of it all is worth the $$. Meals like this stay with you past digestion. I highly recommend this stupendous restaurant and hope you enjoy it as much as we did. Thank You Paul Robuchon.

photos.caption: Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Amazing food experience

xlMol0Pm4L6iQH_sLHG7BA.text: We really looked forward to a perfect experience but only a couple things that semi ruined our time.  There was an obnoxious older couple that kept blowing their noses quite loudly into the napkins. It happened several times during our meal which made it difficult to enjoy.  Other than that service was nice.  We had the 16 course tasting menu and loved every bite. We received copies of our menu and a bag of goodies to take.  Highly recommend trying this indulgent adventure once!

amKV26tKSx1WlpSKvUwVgA.text: Went back and while the service and presentation are still good, I just don't think the food is awesome.  It looks great, but I was consistently not a huge fan of the dishes. And while the higher level wine pairings are predictably awesome, the lower level pairing is really not very good (but at a price point where it should be excellent itself).

alLqwKHvNVNSfWiU5ysFmg.text: Absolutely fantastic in every way!   Service is impeccable.   Food spectacular.  Wine list is awesome, William can definitely help you pick a great wine. Intimate setting, perfect for a date. The fried egg in phylo dough was definitely a crowd pleaser.  The poulet fermier is a must, and yes, I know it is chicken...but it will be some of the best you have ever had. The crab salad, basically a deconstructed salad was off the charts.   Save room and pace yourself, it is a lot of food.

XdRkSOi1F1-8wV-4By9jkg.text: The eponymous Joel Robuchon restaurant is the only restaurant in Las Vegas boasting 3 Michelin stars, and they are well deserved!  Even New Yorkers have to settle for a mere 1-star Atelier which is not the same.   As such, this restaurant is worth a trip out west.    I opted not for the full degustation menu, but rather the next largest choice, the 6 course prix fixe meal.  It turned out to be an exceptionally good meal with very attentive service and an especially knowledgeable sommelier.   Bread Course:  An odd start, but the selection was extensive.  I liked their cheese brioche, and the option of Normandy butter served on a cold slate was just lovely.    Amuse Bouche: Ossetra caviar served over fresh crab with a cream sauce.  I was confused when this was brought to me, as I thought this belonged to the Degustation menu.  But, no, in Joel Robuchon's world, caviar works as an amuse bouche.  How decadent!  I was so enthused by this most auspicious of beginnings.   Appetizer:  Noix de Saint Jacques:  Sea scallop a la plancha with a sauce of kumquat and caviar.  More caviar!  Perfectly seared scallops and beautifully presented.  All of the flavors were in balance -- an excellent course.  Soup:  Le Soja:  Cappuccino of soy bean on a shimeji royal.  The description does not sound very appetizing, and the presentation is only marginally better.  Nonetheless, this is an amazing soup.  So earthy, and the flavor was so robust.  The mushrooms were delicious, and I was really impressed by just how good this dish was.  A True chef can be measured by the quality of his soup -- bravo!  Seafood course:  Langouste:  Spiny lobster in a sake broth, turnip and shiso sprouts.  They actually present this with the spiny lobster shell which they immediately take away, unveiling the dish underneath.  The sake broth was quite delectable and well flavored by the addition of the turnips and sprouts.  Unfortunately,  I was rather disappointed with the langouste itself, a house specialty no less.  I was unable to glean any flavor from it, and the texture was slightly chalky.  This was far short of the langouste I had at Per Se a few months ago, for example.  A strange miss in an otherwise incredible meal.  Meat course:  Canard:  Duck and seared foie gras in a cherry sauce and fresh almonds.  The duck was especially good.  The foie gras was not.  It was too fatty, in a way that is not good.  But the duck was so good, I would just as happily do without the foie gras.  Cheese course:  Another extensive selection that would stump all but the most ardent of turophiles.  I made pedestrian choices like Camembert and Roquefort.  But I also tried some new cheeses like Langres, which apparently I do not like.  All of the selections were fresh, served at the appropriate temperature, and of very high quality.  It was a great way to finish my red wine, and cleanse my palate before having dessert.    Le Chocolat:  Melting Araguani chocolate refreshed with a hint of peppermint.  Exquisitely presented on its own pedestal, this is an extraordinary dessert.    Complimentary dessert: Vanilla ice cream served on a crisp.  Very good ice cream with good quality vanilla bean, likely of the Madagascar variety.    Mignardises:  I thought the bread trolley and the cheese trolley were large, but I clearly had not seen the dessert trolley.  It must have taken about 10 minutes to review all of the possible selections.  Gold leaf was liberally used, and I was happy to see more exotic selections like banana filled chocolates.  Takeaway bag:  pistachio cake.  I am still eating this.  It is a wonderful keepsake to make the amazing experience last a little bit longer, and it is good too.    Highly recommend.  Book your flight now.
