S9mCi8up-JDM26kScsHmEw.text: Extravagant dinning experience. Very impressive service. Food was exceptional. Great ambience in the restaurant. Three stars Michelin rating very well deserved. One of the finest dining experience I've had myself.

-WpGWSFzJXc3LAhNFVO4LQ.text: If any place is fitting of the word perfect it is Joel Robuchon in Las Vegas. Been here three times, twice for the 16 course degustation and once for the Prix Fixe 6 course meal. Start to finish, it's like eating dinner in Heaven. From the opening of caviar and crab, to the magnificent bread cart that is the bread cart of all bread carts, to the beautiful desserts, gorgeous room, flawless service. Yes it's not cheap. If you want the best meal in the U.S.A though, its with saving up for!

Y95LvFAd1OandL05NY_6oQ.text: Visit three, Items experienced:  Le Coeur Rouge - Pomegranate Juice, Muddled Orange and Cherry, Sprite  Le Maize - Corn Veloute, Honey and Ginger Crouton, Smoked Duck, Milk Marshmallow  Bread Service: Mini Baguette, Yeast Bun, Mini Croissant, Gruyere Brioche, Potato Bread, Comte Baguette, Rustic Loaf, Saffron Focaccia, Milk Bread, Bacon with Whole Grain Mustard, Traditional Baguette, Olive Baguette, Basil Focaccia, Brioche with Roasted Sea Salt, French Butter with Sea Salt and Olive Oil  Le Foie Gras - Carpaccio of Foie Gras and Potatoes Covered with Black Truffle Shavings  Le Kabocha - Kabocha Pumpkin Veloute with Foie Gras, Ginger Foam, Toasted Seeds  Les Spaghettis - Homemade Spaghetti Topped with Soft Boiled Egg, Urchin, Caviar  La Pintade Fermiere - French Hen with Roasted Foie Gras, Confit Potatoes au Jus  Cheese Course with Raisin roll, Wildflower honey; Haystack Peak, Cremont, 2 Year Comte, Tomme de Brebis, Pont l'eveque  Le Ruby - Raspberry Dome on Mascarpone Cream, Cranberries, Cranberry Coulis, Japanese Yogurt  Le Chocolat - Apple Compote infused with Hibiscus, topped with Chocolate Tuille, Dark Chocolate Sorbet, Gold Leaf  Petit Fours - Pineapple Financier, Vanilla Macaron, Passionfruit Marshmallow, Apple Cupcake with Caramel Icing, Religeuse, Pear Gelee, Almond Cluster, Cinnamon Meringue, Chocolate Caramels,  Hazelnut/Rum/Banana/Chinese Five Spice Milk Chocolate, Yuzu/Pistachio/Coffee/Passionfruit Dark Chocolate, Coffee Opera Cake, Mango Tarte, Coffee Eclair, Pineapple Tart, Nougat, Blueberry White Chocolate, Citrus Tuille, Hazelnut Bon-Bon, Lemon Tartelette, Dark Chocolate Macaron, Orange Lollipop, Guava Pate a Fruit, Canale, Mini Chocolate Hazelnut Tart, Creme Brulee, Panna Cotta  Orange Sorbet, Caramel Ice Cream, Orange Spice, Anise, Ginger, Caramel Drizzle Cake  Take home gift - Raspberry and Pistachio Pound Cake  ...while some may believe that one cannot buy class, in Las Vegas I'm rather certain that one can buy a close semblance to anything, a fact evidenced by the t-shirt and track suit clad group sitting a few tables down from me as the clock turned to Christmas 2012 while I enjoyed a complimentary piece of Orange Ice cream cake that pastry chef Kamel Guechida had crafted for the questionably clad but clearly affluent Europeans who were celebrating a birthday in addition to the holidays at Vegas' most glitzy restaurant.  Having already dined at Joel Robuchon twice myself this was not the first time I'd seen such generosity from the kitchen of "The Chef of the Century" and much like my previous visits the meal was an exercise in refinement; the room, the food, and the service all well-manicured, highly polished, and lavish.  Taking a 9:00pm reservation and arriving early only to be identified by name as the doors swung open on my approach I was subsequently seated at the same table I'd dined at during my first visit and greeted by a familiar service team including the same dining room manager and server as my prior visit much of what would follow was familiar; the plethoric bread cart and equally impressive cheese course followed by a dessert trolley with nearly three dozen options plus the signature pound cake, though this time smaller than prior.  Deferring on coffee I was additionally treated to a hand clipped tea and infusions cart and a $10 flat charge brought no less than three bottles of Evian - no doubt the cost of admission warrants these things as well as the impressive "Ruby" palate cleanser and "Maize" amuse - gifts that would constitute proper courses at many restaurants.  Moving on to what was ordered I once again opted to order from the prix fixe as opposed to the larger grand tasting and making a special request for the (menu price $300 if ordered ALC) Pintade Fermiere my only small complaint regarding the entire evening was that Chef Le Tohic felt need to visit my table before the hen's preparation to suggest I'd be better off only ordering half the bird as I'd have gladly (and greedily,) eaten more of the crispy skin and supple flesh sandwiched around thick, buttery, foie gras...though I guess saving the $60 supplement charge was a benefit.  Truffles, foie gras, uni, foie gras, caviar, and more foie gras plus aged comte, spell-binding desserts, and a room and service beyond reproach I can think of much worse ways to celebrate Christmas Eve than with Joel Robuchon's team at the MGM and although I personally would never do so in a T-shirt there is something refreshing about the fact that in a city where there are so many bad high-stakes bets this is a place where anyone willing and able to spend the money is virtually guaranteed an excellent return.

qnNlIlVSk9zXSbh6-wSx8w.text: This is one of those restaurants that gets me really excited to write a review. Looking back at my pictures, I'm already looking forward to another visit.   We opted for the six course menu - $240 per person which includes: an amuse bouche, appetizer, soup, two entrees, cheese, dessert, plus the sweet little bites at the end.   We started with the rose champagne and then ordered a couple of bottles of wine. In the end, it was expensive. Like, earn a free flight on your rewards credit card kind of expensive... but... for some people dropping a grand or more on a pair of shoes is their thing. Me? I like to eat.  At first I thought it might be kind of lame but the limo pick up and drop off was beyond a nice touch. When I heard "gold" limousine I instantly pictured something bright, gaudy and sequinced. Nope. It's subdued, the driver is profession and it sets you up for a rather lavish event.   When you arrive they seat you in a beautiful salon/parlor to wait for someone to escort you back to the restaurant. Who knew there were (starting at) $5000 a night mansions hidden away at the MGM? You get to walk past them on your way into the restaurant. Hmmm.... must think of a way to become super rich...  They sat us in a small room which resembles a patio. For the longest time we were the only people there. It was comfortable. Dark. Quiet without seeming stuffy. If they brought me out food all night I would have stayed there forever. There was nothing Vegas tacky about the experience. 5 star, high class every step of the way...  I won't rehash every dish but my favorites were the scallop ceviche, the beef ribeye and the pea soup. Actually, come to think of it, everything was amazing and the presentation of each dish was incredible.   The whole evening was beyond special. A night, an experience we'll both remember for a long time to come.   Do I dare say it? Even without the full desgustation menu, I put Joel Robuchon on par with the French Laundry. I used to hit up Chef Robuchon's little sister restaurant l'Atelier every time I came to Vegas but I think we just found a new tradition.  Joel Robuchon is a fantastic restaurant and definitely makes my top five list...

Cyij6vjTM7eC6aCktWNbRA.text: I should admit, this restaurant is one of the best I have ever been too. The atmosphere is very chic, the services outstanding and the food is fantastic. The menu is unique and I understand why they have 3 Michelin stars. They totally deserve it. The wine list is exceptional. We tried 18 course dinner and it was phenomenal. Every course was an art and not only beautiful but also delicious. The chef is very talented!

U8zaklYwQiH-lkheTwqikg.text: Joel Robuchon get's 4.5 stars for me. This was one of the most amazing restaurants I've been to in my entire life, but there are some things that prevent me from giving this 5 stars. I'll explain in detail.  After arriving, I was checked into a small lounge that is located off the dining room. It's a swanky little place that had a mini bar and some really comfortable lounge chairs. Then, I made my way into the dining room.  The dining room was probably one of the most visually stunning rooms I've ever been to. It was a mix of modern, and elegance. There is also a small outdoor-ish area which has a marvelous vertical garden.  After choosing a menu, that's when the show truly begins. The service here makes you feel like you are John D. Rockefeller. First class all the way. It's elaborate and it makes you feel truly special. This might be the best service I've ever been a part of, so kudos to that.   The highlight of the meal is the bread service, as well as the desserts at the end. This was probably the best bread I've ever been served at any restaurant. It was literally perfection. And the extraordinary bread goes well with the super high end butter that they use. It made the meal start off on a high note.  Where I felt things sort of fell a little bit short in my expectations were the appetizers and entrees. Now keep in mind, they were really good. They use top of the line ingredients, and the technique is impeccable. But for some reason, it just didn't blow away my expectations, even though it was very good. My favorite had to have been the grilled rib eye, it was probably the best steak I've ever eaten in my life. Other than that, everything was good, just not mind blowing, which I was expecting.   As stated earlier, desserts were another high point to the meal. I rarely get desserts at restaurants because generally, I'm disappointed in a certain way. At Robuchon, their dessert game is on point. The lemon dessert I ordered was light, refreshing, and bold without being too overwhelming. Their way of balancing the taste and textures in their desserts is very skillful. They know how to push you to your edge, without making you fall over. And the mignardises at the end are spectacular, I actually wanted to try everything on that cart, and I'm not even a big dessert guy.  I would definitely recommend Joel Robuchon to anyone who wants a very special dinner. Everything is top of the line, and I understand why some consider this restaurant to be among the very best in the world.

rfh83SREXvXHBOOKP-9WLQ.text: At Joel Robuchon, food is made to look as great as it tastes.  Much like the cavemen used animal fats and vegetable juices to paint murals on walls of stone, it is here that food is used as art, plates are used as canvasses, and the restaurant's dishes take on sculptural forms laden with symbolic meaning.  OCD levels of attention are given to every detail. For example, the staff hand-decorates each plate with a water-soluble paint that comes off when the dishes are washed at the end of the evening, only to be re-applied the next day. The dining room is decorated with legitimate fine art, such as Auguste Rodin's "Age of Airain," a bronze statue of a man celebrating his nudity. Before I opened my mouth, the maitre d' greeted me by name.  On my visit to Robuchon, I ordered the Degustation Menu ($445), a marathon tasting of 18 unique dishes, breads, and take-home treats, consisting of the following:  Le Caviar Imperial: Oscetra caviar served atop of king crab in a crustacean gelee dotted with cauliflower puree L'Artichaut Violet: Violet artichoke and foie gras salad with parmesan shavings Le Homard du Maine: Maine lobster in a thinly sliced turnip with sweet and sour dressing L'Asperge Verte: Green asparagus mimosa-style with wasabi cream and caviar L'Oeuf de Poule: Semi-soft boiled egg on a spinach puree with comte cheese sauce L'Asperge Blanche: White asparagus with black garlic, shiso and Esplette pepper La Langoustine: Truffled langoustine raviolo in a foie gras sauce with simmered green cabbage La Crevette Rose: Rose Shrimp in bonito tuna and kombu seaweed broth with ginger L'Oursin: Delicate flan of sea urchin on potato puree topped with Arabica coffee foam La Noix de Saint Jacques: Seared scallop in green curry with young leek Le Foie Gras de Canard: Duck foie gras in crispy gyoza with simmered celery Le Saint-Pierre: John Dory fish fillet with shiso leaf tempura on squid ink risotto Le Pigeon: Roasted squab and foie gras wrapped in green cabbage and bacon L'Hibiscus: Shaved ice with hibiscus syrup Le Matcha: Raspberry-cherry blossom compote Le The Earl Grey: Earl Grey tiramisu with mascarpone Le Papillon Chocolat Azelia: Hazelnut milk chocolate cremeux with coffee chantilly and praline ice cream Miscellaneous Candies and Pound Cake (to take home, "for tomorrow's breakfast")  Yelp's character limit prevents me from commenting on all of these dishes individually, though collectively they were excellent.   I was hit between my eyes with the luxurious beauty of the tasting's initial offering: the delicate Le Caviar Imperial is perhaps better known as caviar araignee de mer, or caviar "spider of the sea," and is a work of art sprinkled with flakes of gold. The fresh, buttery caviar was so plentiful in my mouth, it felt like I was chewing a caviar steak coated with the flavorful jellied crustacean consomme it sat in.  The eyeball-like L'Oeuf de Poule was magnificent both to look at and to eat -- pulling off a culinary magic trick that confounded me: a de-shelled egg with a hard-boiled white but with a liquid runny yolk inside. My excellent waiter, Andrew, indicated sous-vide, but I know this can't be accomplished with traditional sous-vide alone -- either the yolks would solidify or the whites would remain soft.  My main course was Robuchon's wickedly-rich squab stuffed with foie gras, with its unlikely but welcomed addition of cabbage and bacon. Le Pigeon was also served with Pommes Robuchon, the world-famous silky, micro-sieved mashed potatoes that maintain an outrageous 2:1 potatoes-to-butter ratio.  Delicious breads were peddled from a bread cart containing close to 20 different options to choose from throughout the meal. I chose a croissant, a milk roll, and an odd (but tasty) bread featuring bacon and mustard seed.  Some of the other tasting stand-outs included the delightful squid ink risotto served with the fish fillet, the rose shrimp served in the umami-rich ocean-y broth, the refreshing shaved ice with hibiscus syrup, and the heavenly chocolate hazelnut dessert with its glamorous edible butterflies made of sugar.  Was it worth the price? That's a personal question that each person needs to decide for themselves. I know people who would burn $500 on slot machines without a second thought, but would consider spending the same amount on a meal in Vegas to be a foolish waste of money. With this restaurant, you're not gambling. Joel Robuchon is Las Vegas's only restaurant to earn Michelin's Three Stars in addition to earning AAA's Five Diamonds, and has now taken residence on my top 5 list of dining experiences. Unlike Adria or Redzepi, Robuchon won't be turning this restaurant into an "art center" or "urban farm" or other grand experiment any time soon -- it is, after all, consistency and predictability that has won him more Michelin Stars than any chef in the world. If you're going to spend some money on dining in Las Vegas, it should be here.  Food/Decor/Service: 4.9/4.7/4.8

ZluaRJPJAkeXbxlegKgOaw.text: Made an impromptu decision to come here after a series of disappointing 'fine dining' experiences on the strip and was immediately relieved the moment we stepped into Joel Robuchon.  This hidden sanctuary is tucked away at a far corner of MGM that allows you to escape the noise and bustle of Vegas.  It was truly a classy experience from the moment we walked it.  We were seated next to a beautiful indoor garden with plush velvet seats.  There were about 3 servers waiting on our table with impeccable attention to detail.  We ordered the 17 course tasting menu which was amazing from start to finish.  Lots of French classics like caviar and foie gras in creative small plates that came in trios.  There was a slight delay in between some of our courses when they became busy but the manager picked up on it immediately after seeing us look around and our next dish came promptly.  I noticed the two tables seated next to us ordered a la carte and the dishes that came out looked equally impressive.  I know that sometimes restaurants only impress in their tasting menus while the regular menu falls short, but this does not seem to be the case for Joel Robuchon.  I overheard some pretty interesting items being described that I would love to try next time.  They also have a large variety of breads and mini desserts that comes in an extravagant display cart, which I found pretty unique.  The only downside is I wish I could've eaten more of it.  Even the bread was delicious and I'm normally not a big bread eater.  I became way too full by dessert and couldn't properly taste all of it - dessert comes in 3 parts!  One of the desserts was a life like rose decorated with dewdrops of water that I almost did not want to eat because it was a True work of art.  My friend who is not a dessert fan was so impressed by the look and taste of this.  Probably not a bad idea to skip lunch if you want to try to full tasting menu.  Of course this comes with a hefty price tag, but if you're planning on splurging on something nice then this is more worth it than most Vegas establishments.  There are way too many high end restaurants on the strip that razzle and dazzle but fails on the actual food.  I was so glad this was not the case here and we look forward to coming back on our next visit!

KlhZjGWSnrMAul8cp7NFbw.text: I hate to give such a beautiful restaurant 1 star, but the food was absolutely tragic! I have never been to a restaurant where I hated everything I tried, however this was a first.    The decor inside was truly amazing. Beautiful flowers and a pretty chandelier. The service was good and the empty plates did not sit long.   The bread cart, unfortunately, was the best thing about this place when it came to the food. I worried when I saw nothing on the dessert side that would justify an extra $30, so we did not bother. Then when it came to the appetizers, I did not enjoy the fact that you are about to pay a hell of a lot of money for dinner and then all the dishes that looked really good had extra charges, surcharge as they called it, tacked on them. The entrees were the same. If it sounded good there was an extra charge for it. Probably for the truffle, but really? With the amount of cash this place makes you can't throw a customer a bone and give a little truffle?  My girlfriend had the beef carpaccio appetizer. If I could have spit it out at the table I would have. Instead I ate it and then had the horrible taste left in my mouth, and felt like it was swimming in my stomach. The flavor was almost indescribable. Like nothing I have ever tasted. Wood? Earthy? All around made me gag. And my appetizer was the main lobster with daikon. Again the taste was awful. No sauce, nothing really on the plate. Tasted like wood again. Both were REALLY bad.  The main course selections had no great things to choose from, but I figured fish and risotto...can't go wrong right? Well the John Dory fish was over cooked. The tempura leaf on top lacked flavor and was pointless on top of the fish. The fish itself had zero flavor and was dry. Again no sauce. And the squid ink risotto had zero flavor. It was literally rice with some squid ink.  It came with  potatoes, which could not save any part of the meal. My girlfriend had the rib eye which looked like 2 long cubes of beef. I wondered where the rest of the cow went. Reminded me of some strange beef stick.   Being from San Francisco we definitely know good food. However we are not overly picky when it comes to food. It's the principle and the price for what we got. The food was honestly some of the worst food we have ever eaten. My poor girlfriend spent $500 to take me here for an early birthday dinner. What a waste. Save your money people. Go to Scarpetta at the Cosmopolitan. The food was soooooo good and much cheaper.

LI0mbLApOLMn6FsNQB2d6Q.text: Food 3 stars  Service 5 stars Atmosphere 5 stars Price  1 star  This place has been on my bucket list for years, along with French Laundry. Due to its price tag, we always procrastinated to try it. Since it was a special occasion, we decided to indulge. Reservation was rather easy make. I called only a week prior to our visit, granted it was for a Tuesday night.   As we entered, the space was elegant and intimate, with rich violet cushioned seats, luxurious drapes, and a statement chandelier. We were seated at a table for two next to an open space leading to the door. It was drafty whenever anyone enters or exits. There were cozy booths available and later on I was later informed by Kit, our favorite Server, that Table 17 in their "Parisian Terrace" was their best table for two. Service was sublime, an orchestra of soft-spoken professionals aiming for a seamless performance. They even had a level three Sommelier, William. Very impressive indeed.  We decided not to go with the $445 degustation menu as Hubby prefers the traditional 3-5 course meal over 16 courses of smaller bites (my preference). Since it was his Birthday dinner, we went with his choice. We both selected the $250 per person 5 Course Dinner with 2 Appetizers, 2 Entrees, and Dessert. Big mistake! It was TOO much food that we both felt like exploding even before the meal was over. By the time we were done, our meal ended up being the same price as the tasting menu due to all the supplemental charges. If we ever go back, we would be quite happy with the $198 4 Course Dinner.  First came the famous bread cart, with about a dozen different varieties of bread, brioche, and croissant. We omitted the sea salt from our butter.  Though I normally shun bread, we could not help but fill up on their divine bread and sweet butter. After that, everything went downhill until dessert.   We both ordered their Signature appetizer, Truffled Langoustine Ravioli with Foie Gras sauce. Hubby ordered the Oscetra Caviar with Salmon Tartar and I got the Chilled Maine Lobster with thinly sliced turnips. Though they were beautifully presented, none of the appetizers were memorable. Then came our first entrees, his was the Pork made three ways (God knows why he ordered pork), and mine was Black Cod served with Baby Bok Choy. The Cod melted in the mouth, similar in style to Japanese Miso Butterfish. Hubby's pork chops were tiny, it was smaller than rack of lamb but he said it was tasty.   Next came the Duck with Coriander, which both of us had to order with a $60 supplement. Nobody warned us that this was an ENTIRE duck for two people! It was interesting to watch the table-side presentation of our waiter slicing the breast meat for us. Then they took the rest of the duck back to the kitchen to make "Duck Tacos". The duck breast was tough, served luke warm, completely under-salted and flavorless. One of the worst Ducks I have had in a French restaurant. Then they brought the Asian-inspired Duck Tacos on a bed of lettuce. The Lettuce was fresh and crisp - sadly, it was the best part of the dish.   Finally we made it to our dessert course. Although I was bursting at the seams, I HAD to order the Chocolate Souffle, and Hubby ordered the lightest dessert available, which was the Lemon Sorbet. We both agreed that our desserts were the HIGHLIGHT of the meal! And I don't even have a sweet tooth. Their heavenly Chocolate Souffle alone was worth coming back for.  By the time they rolled out the dessert cart for after-dinner treats, we were full to the rim. They also surprised us with a lovely Ice-Cream Cake for the Birthday Boy! We each had a slice of the refreshing Passionfruit and Coconut Ice-cream cake.    This place is a classic case of a 3 Michelin Star resting on its laurels. They earned their stars more than a decade ago and Michelin has not been back to Vegas since 2010 to reevaluate. To be honest, we prefer the Classical French cooking at Picasso for less than half the price of the Asian-Fusion style at Robuchon. Perhaps we ordered the wrong items or we should have gone with the Tasting Menu, but at over $1K with wine and tip, it had better be mind-blowing!

A5EQq21CoE2jMBzw_2Mufw.text: I've been to many 3 Michelin Star Restaurants, and Joel Robuchon remains a clear winner for the following reasons:  1. The Food. The most important factor, Robuchon's food is always exquisite and top notch. Each one is a work of art, but also a work of flavors. No gimmicky dishes that are all flash and no substance. Everything has purpose.    2. The Menu. The vast majority of other 3-star restaurants only allow for tasting menus. This is to make it easier on the kitchen, but it forces everyone into the same menu, which may not be to everyone's liking. And while the menu does change seasonally, sometimes you just aren't feeling like eating 14 courses over a 3 hour dinner. Robuchon not only has its tasting menu (which should be everyone's choice on their first visit), but it has much more smaller and affordable set menus, where you can customize what you want.    3. The price. Okay, this place is not cheap by any means, but it's inline with all the other 3 star restaurants. However, they give ALOT more food for that same price. What is a 14 course meal here may only be a 10 course meal in another 3-star restaurant, and that's not including the vast bread and candy selections offered by Robuchon. Not to mention, if you really want to cut down the price, get a fixed set course menu, and you still have access to the bread and candy!  Overall one of my favorite restaurants worldwide, and a very strong recommendation.

YfwwMRTp0ge5KB4p6TAa-w.text: No words would ever be able to accurately describe the wonderful experience I had at Joel Robuchon last night... simply AMAZING. My boyfie, whom I owe everything to now, SURPRISED me with dinner here for being a kickass girlfriend. Am I lucky or nah?   Beyond lucky. :))))  We both ordered the full tasting menu along with the wine pairing. There are 3 tiers for the wine pairing @ $295, $595, and the premium. The sommelier goes over the difference in each price point without being pushy at all. Everything we ate/drank was just absolutely amazing. I can honestly say it's the best meal I've ever had in my life along with the best wine I've ever had in my life. This place was also accommodating to my pescatarian needs, which wasn't that many substitutions since their menu is majority seafood.  Favorites of the night: x Quinoa and red pepper amuse bouche x Oscetra caviar served atop of king crab and a crustacean Gelee x Langoustine ravioli x Lobster wrapped in spinach x Some kind of corn soup/puree (my favorite of the night) x ALL THE BREAD from their bread cart with their ridiculously good butter. I usually hate filling up on bread anywhere, but the bread here is on another level...  Everything was just so over the top, but to perfection. Full tasting menu is the way to go. I highly recommend the wine pairing as well.  Service was great and they were are so very friendly. The only thing I was EH about the entire night was when the boyfie spilled some of my wine and they didn't think/offer to refill it... a fluke perhaps? Regardless, I won't hold that minor hiccup against them. The food was everything. How will I ever be the same again. I can't stop thinking about my meal here :(

oW8_ab3DTPuHkdtaqF1t9g.text: This is as good as it gets. I've eaten at many fine dining restaurants throughout the world and Joel Rubuchon's was hands down, the very best I've ever been to. The moment you walk in you are completely transported to another world, far far away from Vegas, where time seems to stand still.   The level of service and attention to detail are dream like and it all comes across as genuine and so very authentic by every member of this incredible staff. They are very serious about their profession, but have wonderful personalities and a great sense of humor.   They don't serve food, they serve art. The presentation, taste, and experience of every dish is superb. There isn't one element that hasn't been meticulously thought of, toiled to perfection, and taken immense time, pride and imagination to create such beautiful dishes.   And let's not forget the incredible bread, cheese and candy carts. My girlfriend dreams of the incredible selection of fresh made bread and delicious butter and I'm not one bit jealous. How can I blame her?   We spent over three hours there and it felt like an hour. The biggest disappointment was finishing our meal and walking out into the hustle and bustle of the casino. This was truly a magical experience.   Thank you to the wonderful staff who are truly masters of their craft.

AGmrwvkFa2-79tobv-rsYw.text: Summary for what you are about to read below:   Appetizers: 1-2 stars Entrees: 1-2 stars Desserts: 5 stars Service: 5 stars Price: 1 star Overall: 3 stars  Here are the reasons why I only gave this restaurant three stars: We ordered the tasting menu which is $445 per person. There are roughly 17 different plates before you end up with an after dessert cart that you can choose pastries from. Without getting too detailed, we ordered the current tasting menu for April of 2017. It had a lot of seafood on it and some foie gras. All of the dishes, across the board, from the appetizer to the entree, were underwhelming and just OK. I would never order any of these dishes again. Quite frankly, I believe I can get way better seafood at average seafood restaurants that cost a lot less money than this restaurant. One of the plates was a poached egg with some spinach puree around it... What? It was bland and terrible. For $445, I simply got a poached egg?!  Had it not been for the bread basket at the beginning and the dessert and after dessert cart, everything from the appetizer to the entree would have gotten one star from me. I am not joking as I disliked the meal that much and could not believe I was taking bites of it. I was trying to justify the fact that I would be paying for this meal after ordering it. I know phenomenal restaurants. I am blessed enough to be well-traveled and love amazing food. I have the means to also go to top places. This place may be rated as a three Michelin star restaurant, but it is nowhere near any Michelin star by my standards until I got to dessert, which simply put is the star of the show. Maybe, if I ordered off the menu rather than the tasting menu, I would have liked it more. There is a high-end restaurant that looks like a circus tent covering it at the Bellagio that is cheaper than this restaurant and way better from the appetizer all the way to dessert and has incredible wine pairings that this restaurant simply did not open up about in terms of how much it would cost to do that. The total meal, for tasting menu for two people, a Pinot Noir bottle at $175, with tax and tip of 20%, came out to $1400. Yes, very expensive and not worth it!  If this restaurant allowed simply for ordering dessert, we would be back in a heartbeat. I don't think I would want to eat another meal here as I was that underwhelmed. There are too many other amazing places in Las Vegas to go to and this one really disappointed me. The restaurant is gorgeous, the service is very nice, and you even get a pound cake, lemon flavored, to go home with as a gift in the end which is very nice. It is lovely for special occasions if you're looking for a phenomenal ambiance. I would order off the menu itself and I would not do the tasting menu as this was the first time I was very disappointed with a tasting menu. Dessert gets 5 stars, as does the bread basket at the beginning, so it averages out to three stars.

zkwiYlw821NKJ_Z6XZJKNw.text: My first 3 Michelin restaurant ever. Created by a legend/master in his craft. The attention to detail in the flavors, the ambiance and decor, the plating marked me and changed my way of looking at fine dining for good.

1eJSOoNjWOxQKJZZf77W1Q.text: This is the most expensive meal I've ever eaten but it was amazing.  First off the interior is amazing. The decor and waitstaff uniforms is a very interesting but well pulled off. It is a elegant combination of upscale early 1900s European feel with an east Asian touch.  I couldn't come here and not get their full tasting menu. At this point I can't remember exactly how many courses there were but easily more than you can count on your fingers. It will set you back around $500 per person with or without wine pairings but if you can afford it, it is definitely an experience. There are a few smaller tasting menus if you are not as hungry or looking to eat a little cheaper.  The food is just amazing to taste and look at. One of the desserts could only be described as a mini art sculpture (See the picture I posted. Everything in the picture minus the glass bowl was edible and amazing). The courses had everything from things simple as a beat mustard salad to a seafood mousse topped with caviar. All of it fantastic.   Others have written about it but the bread cart itself is a site to behold. I was tempted to ask what it would cost me to come back and just be able to sit, drink wine, and eat off the bread cart. I also love that the bread cart is continued to be brought to you at request throughout the meal.   One of the more impressive experiences was the service. Not just from the wait staff but from everything. The instance that stands out the most was during the meal with one of the courses. I really enjoyed it. My wife was not a fan of this particular course. I cleared my plate and she had a few bites and set it aside. The waiter asked her if there was anything wrong, and she simply replied it wasn't to her taste. With that the waiter politely cleared our plates in preparation for the next course. In less than 10 minutes before the next actual course came out the waiter brought my wife a new dish, and explained it was something special from the chef as an apology that she had not enjoyed the last course. It was fantastic and I  was impressed that they took it upon them self to do this without any asking or prompting.   Save some of your gambling money and come here. It is worth it.

b0HlwBJrXzhiUGFfW9fmtg.text: 17 courses.  Exquisite environment.  Exceptional service.  I will let the photos tell the story.  What can you say?  Welcome to The Matrix!

0uT0HumiK_aPGp458n-pOw.text: The service was pretty good. It was not impeccable as the price would incline. The food was beautiful but it was NOT delicious.  Honestly I feel like I overpaid. The food was... FAR from delicious.

qr6_8u7k_Jh6dSMhYBuffg.text: Had a lovely dining experience for my birthday this evening.   I thought i was gonna go for the full 16 or 17 plate course but decided i didn't think i would be able to finish it all.   I chose the one appetizer and one main with dessert and it was plenty of food for me.   For the appetizer, the caviar with salmon sparked my interest since i've never tried it before. I felt i'd either hate it or love it. And i loved it! Very rich, and the mixture of flavors were very pleasant to the palette.    My main was equally as delicious. I chose the beef bouffe i think thats what it was called (Basically the ribeye) and it was very tender and flavorful along with everything else on the plate.   Dessert... There was so much dessert! We ordered dessert and also got some from the tray and also got served cake since it was my bday! Everything was delicious. Try the black forest, choco souffle, praline chocolate, passion fruit macaron, eclairs, coffee, strawberry tart... They're all delicious!  The ambiance of the restaurant is very quiet and intimate which was a stark contrast to any restaurant i've been to ever. Feels very classy and proper... I felt not as relaxed as i am at a place like nobu but it was a different kind of dining experience i enjoyed.   Service was fabulous along with the food and i would recommend it to anyone!

5LTE-Gq_pvVH9YphtlgDhA.text: Really not that great and SO overpriced. I came here December 2018 because I wanted to try a Joel Robuchon menu before it changed and was no longer his. I chose the tasting menu which ended up being $575 after tip and tax (think of all the street tacos you could buy with that). The best dish was the Caviar Imperial which was the first dish and then it was all pretty "meh" from there. There wasn't a single taste or combination that was innovative/I hadn't tasted before and the courses weren't that good themselves. Everything felt like it could have been made....better. The service was good, whatever. Bread and dessert cart were cool but not that cool. The highlight of my dinner was having these 5 tacky purple bejeweled rhinestones in the middle of my table that I couldn't stop fiddling with. They also give you a WHOLE pound cake at the end to make you feel better about how much money you just spent but not sure if it was good or not as I didn't eat it.

_LkkNzVy9REFhC97RIXaPA.text: I've been in love with Chef Robuchon (more like his food) since 2009, when I set my foot for the very first time in L'Aterlier next door. Since then I've made it a mission to visit his other international locations when I travel. Yes, maybe I'm biased here...  Anyway, we came here awhile back, before people even realized there was a Joel Robuchon here, right next to Ka.   There were only 4 tables occupied at the whole dining room that evening, including a food critic, and possibly a smaller group for a semi-private event. It was very quiet, and could be intimidating for some. But I love that atmosphere, as I often find majority of upscale restaurants in the U.S. to be quite loud and once in awhile, I just want to have that one nice meal quietly without hearing what's going on at nearby tables.   Service was great, and we had the full attention from the staff. They made sure everything was done right and we were taken care of for even the smallest request. Very attention to detail.   Food wise, I'm always a fan. Everything was done to perfection. But what I LOVE the most was the bread cart and dessert cart, and that becomes the reason why I'd skip L'Aterlier to come here or similar restaurants such as Le Chateau in Tokyo, because I want to be able to choose my desserts. And goodie bags at the end of the evening is always a plus too... (yum)  I did hear from another friend who just visited here a few months ago that the place is quite popular now and maybe the crowds make some difference to the experience. I guess I'll have to go back again to find out myself.

iKtkHukp_W-uMd_V4CyHow.text: With the recent passing of Chef Robuchon, I wanted to share my memory of my dinner back in April. I'm not sure what else could be said of this restaurant that hasn't already been said. Every single minute detail has been thought out regarding the presentation of food and the environment that you experience it in.  Over the course of 19 individual dishes, the tasting menu took me on a journey that I have thought about very regularly since I have gone several months ago. Before I mention the perfectly prepared food however, I would like to offer my praise for our serving captain Nathan -- along with his supporting staff -- who provided a level of service that far exceeds any experience I've had in the past. Given the special occasion and our younger age, I appreciated Nathan bringing a slightly less formal and more amicable personality to the table, but through the excellence of his service, I have a hard time imagining him not giving a table perfect, formal service at the highest level if he had a sense that was what they wanted. All the textbook formalities were performed perfectly: greeting and serving the lady first, crumbing the table only when one is excused for the restroom, bringing out each glass of wine at the perfect time, an astute knowledge of everything on the menu. The service was perfect, but in addition to that he created took a very formal environment and elevated it to a level of entertainment that I have not experienced anywhere else.  Every piece of minutiae regarding the food was presented in the exact same way as the service. The foods served took what was mostly simple ingredients and brought them to such a high level they tasted unlike what you've had before. Bread fresh out of the oven is brought to the table in dozens of varieties. Basil and saffron rolls, bacon twists, and mini baguettes. Tomatoes, Lemon and oil our brought together in a way that exemplifies each ingredient, a generous serving of Osetra carving throughout the lighter dishes, as well as a generous portion of numerous varieties of seafood. Following these dishes is a perfectly cooked American Wagyu ribeye served with two wonderful sauces, crisp tempura battered shallots and the pinnacle of refinement: Robuchon's Pomme Puree.   Following the entrees and main course are four perfectly prepared, visually stunning dishes in the forms of various sorbets, cakes, mousses and other patisserie magic. Following the larger dishes was a collection of mignardise, ranging from lollipops, macarons and meringues, as well as an excellent assortment to take with us due to a server hearing mentioning that we were almost full. He noted to serve us the harder to transport pastries and then package an assortment of more durable ones to go -- a small, but appreciated detail.  Overall, there are very few places that can charge well over $1,000 for two guests and a few drinks, but if there is one restaurant that can justifiably do so, it is this one. You can go in, expect a perfect meal, and get a perfect meal. So far, it has been the best meal and dining experience of my life.

7QzG7PZrJExaIxNl6v4Z0A.text: Most certainly a meal we will remember for the rest of our lives.  Make reservations well in advance or it's impossible to get in. Dress code is no joke...Men, bring that jacket.  Service is formal but attentive.  The bread and dessert treat carts alone are worth it.  This is food artistry at its absolute finest - beautiful AND delicious.    Don't miss their signature gin and tonic: juniper berries and some exotic lime leaf.  Everything was exquisite!

eexzJR4GarD9bFIbJjALpA.text: Food nirvana! Worth a trip to Vegas alone.  Get the wine pairing and prepare to stay a while.  The full degustation menu to us about 3 hours to finish, but honestly it went by quite quickly.  The dishes come in multiple tasting trios so it doesn't feel like you have endless plate exchanges. As usual the desserts were crazy over the top and there so many of them that it was kind of ridiculous. We even went home with a pound cake!

photos.caption: Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dessert terrarium. There&#39;s some white chocolate in there.
Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Too complex to explain. Taste buds exploded.
Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Signature mashed potatoes are pillows of goodness.

39dhtfmMgZbcUH6SxoRq1Q.text: The price is steep, but the quality is the best you can possibly hope for in Las Vegas.  Stepping into the restaurant is so unique.  On either side of the opening you have a Cirque show and slot machines, then you walk into a prestige, clean area with all waiters wearing suits.  Not the biggest area with only a few dozen tables, but very cozy and well groomed atmosphere with chandeliers and real flowers on the walls.  The food was high quality French.  Each dish of the degustation seemed very seasonal and had a chef's tough with either the design or cooking technique to give it the taste or texture desired.  The best part of any high dining experience is that the chef will recommend an order or a way to eat the dish.  This means the chef expects a reaction not the dish and in my opinion makes it better than just an entree and dig in, while mixing ingredients not intended for each other.  But there are too many dishes to discuss from the degustation as it's about a 17 plate tasting with extra desserts and bread.    The bad parts to begin the review.  Firstly, the chef's insistence on asparagus.  They were in about 5 dishes either in soup or grilled form.  Never added any taste and the flavor overwhelmed.  The pace was extremely slow as well.  With a tasting such as this, I expected a new dish to come out every 10 minutes or so.  Instead, Robuchon would bring out 3 dishes at a time, and then expect you to wait 30 minutes for the next - poor structure.  Bread service should have been nonstop as well, only when we asked for more were we brought.  Finally, the vegetarian tasting was absurdly basic.  About 7-8 of our dishes between regular and inveterate were identical.  The other vegetarian dishes were just more of the same vegetables with only a couple memorable items such as tempura tofu and ravioli.  Otherwise, you were just eating side vegetable dishes all night with no high end additions such as caviar or foie gras.  And not to mention, this is the same price as the regular.  The price obviously is high and expected so I wouldn't put it as a negative but just a choice - buyer beware.  The good were all meats.  From the entree steak to two separate lobster courses, to a strong scallop - all were delicious.  Foie gras and caviar gave it the high end feel, as did the smoked salmon.  The bread was very good, especially with the amount of selection and the fact that they heat it up for you upon ordering.  The dessert was out of this world in terms of flavor and beauty and selection, with the tasting menu's signature dessert more or less a jungle of different flavors.  Also, being a birthday or anniversary type of venue, they are always prepared to have something special for you if you let them know ahead of time  The wine list can get high, but honestly wasn't absurd with many options in the price range of a regular steakhouse on the strip.  $50 corkage fee is a great deal as well considering the price point of the meal.  And a goody bag to go with a nice pistachio and fruit cake is always a fantastic touch.  The experience was great and I would never take that back.  And looking at the regular menu, you can easily come for a $200 tasting and get a great fancy meal.  Robuchon is high class in Vegas and a once a year type of dining.  Food was great and hit every tastebud I was hoping for.  Very glad I had the opportunity to dine here.

FMPK4Rsumw0ktoAsHDP_mA.text: Got to go back to our favorite restaurant around this past weekend and it did not disappoint.  We have been here 6 or 7 times and leave wowed each time.  We have only done the degustation menu once, the first time we went.  It was just too much food and since then have seemed to settle in on the 4 course option (2 apps, 1 entree, 1 dessert).  This meal they started with two amuse bouches which was a pleasant surprise since in the past I can only remember one.  The first one I missed what it was.  It was breaded and extremely rich bite.  The second amuse was a chilled corn soup with creme fraiche and caviar.  The last few times we have had a similar amuse, with it being a gazpacho since we have usually been there during the summer.  They have a bread cart with 30 different options to choose between.  The chooses have been the same over each of our visits which isn't a problem since they are all good and there are so many.  Keep in mind that they only warm the first set of bread you get, after that it will be straight from the cart.  I usually stick to the warm appetizers but this time I started with chicken egg filled with king crab and caviar.  Wife went with the pumpkin veloutte with alba white truffles.  Both were spectacular.  From there we both had the truffled langostines.  This is 3 langostine raviolis filled and topped with truffle in a foie gras butter emulsion.  This is my single favorite dish I have had at any restaurant.  There hasn't been a time we have gone to Robuchon's and not ordered this.  We matched again on dishes with the entree, both selecting the spit roasted duck.  We may have just not been paying attention but we couldn't remember ever seeing duck as an option before on our previous visits.  This was a good rendition.  We have had some absolute standout versions at other places like EMP that would put above this one.  We ended with dessert this time.  Wife went for the chocolate souffle.  I did a tayberry coulis.  Wife thought this was the best souffle she has had.  I very much liked my dessert too, as it was light and beautifully plated.    Hint, you can substitute the cheese trolley for the dessert which is what we normally do since you will get plenty of sweets with the dessert cart.  Speaking of dessert cart, this is something that is a True standout.  The mignardises are fantastic.  They have 40+ different options.  Can't say enough about this place.  It is a special dinner place where you are going to spend $$$$$$$$$$$$$.  Go into this expecting to leave a little poorer but you should leave really satisfied on the quality of food.

pOKvGs1N_N8uZ580NEz0jw.text: Group of friends and I booked a reservation here. There were 8 of us and so we booked 2 tables. If you have a group of 7 or more you'd have to order a set menu whereas smaller groups are able to pick from the different menu sets.   It was such a surprise when we got there and was informed that they had set us up in a private room and still allowed us to pick out different sets.  The private room was amazing! It was very extravagant - front the table setting to the chandelier.   Our waiter, Yann, was both very professional and hilarious! He explained all of our meals well and answered all of our questions. He made our dinner such a great experience.  The food was great and the plating, especially the dessert, was very well done. And like others have previously said the bread and dessert carts are to die for!   Definitely worth the money!

mW6yP6Ff8xpQ8t4bN4te1g.text: I'm just going to get straight to the point as to why I'm only giving this place 2 stars. I love fine dining. And to be frank with you, I'm willing to pay the extra bens if the dining experience is actually worth it. But here? Nah. What I didn't like about this place is there wasn't any speciality dishes. For the price I paid, I wasn't expecting to be a served a hard boiled egg, deep fried poached egg or raw salmon as my appetizers. Come on Joel, whip me up something that I can't eat anywhere else. Give me a reason to come back. I was here for your signature dishes but you definitely failed me.   The main entrees here were a bit underwhelming. The rib eye was good but unfortunately I had better steak elsewhere. Prime Steakhouse or the A5 Japanese Wagyu at Picasso in the Bellagio is much more deserving of a 5 star rating in my books.  1 star for the beautiful food presentation.  1 star for the service.

photos.caption: Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Complimentary ice cream cake in celebration of our wedding anniversary!
Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salmon with caviar and edible gold leaves.

bXphYlhyF_mAfY-OOLENiQ.text: Fine dining at its best!  I've had the pleasure and honor to dine here more than 5 times, and every time it is... se magnifique!   Highlights:  Food - I love technique and presentation. Every dish is well thought out in terms of presentation of the food, plate ware, colors, and then elevated with some sort of foam, gelee, flavor layering, and/or intricate presentation. You almost feel bad for eating such a lovely piece of artwork... almost ;) Some of my favorites have been:  -Caviar Crab Salad/Parfait -Joel Robuchon Mashed Potatoes -Salad of Tomato/Gelee  Bread Cart - so many to choose from!  10+ daily baked breads are rolled out to you for selection. After you pick out your heart's desire, it is heated and brought back to you. I love the breads, but I love the butter more! Imported French butter curled tableside and sprinkled with sea salt. Such a Beautiful presentation!   Candy Cart - again, so many to choose from!  I lost count of how many they offer! But I always muster up my appetite to try at least 6 varietals, ranging from the caramels, candies, bon bons, pastries, chocolates, and more.   Tea Cart - so fresh (literally), and so cool!  Fresh herb plants are rolled to your table for you to choose. Upon your selection, the server snipes the plants, cleans the leaves, and brews the tea. It's the only place I've ever seen this type of tea service.   Definitely a once in a lifetime experience to have, if not more! Bon appetit!

Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Our candy selection
Photo of Joël  Robuchon - Las Vegas, NV, United States. THE candy cart

lIQF0nkxhGWxdCzsEyVE3Q.text: One of the FINEST, most EXPENSIVE  meals I have ever had.   The meal was a festival of 16 Delicately crafted, perfectly presented food preparations  each simultaneously awakening my every sense of taste, smell and sight. Joel Robuchons expert marriage of familiar simple flavors and textures were uniquely sophisticated and delightfully new. Equally noteworthy the pastries at meals end were miniature delicately prepared morsels, visually beutiful and devine in taste, in a class above all other pastries I have had before. Joel Robuchon is a culinary experience meal of a lifetime, worth trying.

11DZKhR5Ftz9WboFkgrzQA.text: So it was my wifes birthday and this was a place that was on her list of places to try.  Now this isn't a place you just go to on a whim, you need to make reservation in advance and to be honest you really need to save up especially if your planning on ordering the tasting menu because its going to set you back $500 a person and the whole table must order it.   With that being said, the meal is truly a dining experience.  Every detail is planned out from the first to last course and your going to be impressed with all the different flavors and artistry that goes into the preparation of the food.  The bread and dessert carts are amazing and you will probably want to try everything even if you stomach says no but your brain says yes.

6a2NUD3dAAEv6qXJH7-1Gw.text: Robuchon is located at the MGM Grand. Just valet park and be done with it. You have to meet the food God, you have no time to waste. You walk in, with your reservation, dressed correctly, and you are greeted by a wonderful person who takes you to the start of a food journey you will always remember and dream about later. The place is beautiful. It is comfortable with soft chairs and lovely decorations. It is spotless and you can tell that someone really loves to care for this place. It looks new, although it is not. Once seated you are given menus and you can order from the tasting menu, which is wonderful, or the main menu. There is no going wrong here. Each item is perfect. They bring you bread and oils and butters and you think, this is pretty, after all it is just bread--no it is not, it is pieces of heaven and you can put a tab of butter or try one of the oils and you will know that bread can be all one needs in the world.  They have a full bar and extensive wine list. If you want it, they have it. The food is perfect. It is so lovely you don't want to touch it but you know it is going to be like nothing you have had before. Each bite is something to take slowly and enjoy all the flavor and different tastes all in one bite. The service is perfect, when you want them they are there and they seem to know when to just leave you be in your own little world of food of the Gods.  Order whatever you want. You can't go wrong and save room for desert.  Now, all of this is going to cost you so so much money. It is a very expensive place to dine. There is nothing to order on a budget. But it is worth it, even if just once in your life, it is worth it. I usually say in my reviews to take you kids, but not this time. You can, they are welcome, but I don't know if a 10 year old will understand that he is eating the food of the Gods.  Have the best time.

VEdH2E_JZEeKsehxowCMRA.text: My wife, a super foodie, actually cried of sheer joy when we dined here. Everything was superb.

wt-E0_WIX2D379VFP2n-hg.text: Solid 4.5 stars.  Amazing tasting menu. It's one of the best meal of my life. The sensible progression of delicate flavors proves the meal to be a True master piece. The lavish ingredients were used to bring particular elements in taste and texture to the dishes. My servers were attentive and have great eyes for details.   The only comment I recommend is to reduce the sugar level on the desserts. They were gorgeous and imaginative but it was a tad too sweet.

XVekQfm_xJayH_xmmkyIvQ.text: My husband and I celebrated our first wedding anniversary here. We got the Menu Degustation.... and it was the best fine dining experience we have ever had.   Other fine dining experiences have smaller portions and the timing between the dishes are long.   However, the portion here was just right... the wait between courses were perfect.  In fact, we were so stuffed that we had difficulty breathing at the end.  The staff here were very attentive and friendly. I highly recommend.

wm4TnYaNRXzPHc-iAgHwcA.text: O.M.G. This was a culinary experience of a lifetime! So accomadating and no  detail was not missed!!! I felt so spoiled and every bite and morsel was an international delicacy. The presentation of the food made me feel as if I was in a food art museum! There was a sincerity and story behind each course and was certainly a great Valentine's day surprise!!

2xWlAAkMVGOVilufC1qeQw.text: An amazing experience. The ambiance was absolutely outstanding, I wish I more places were so lavishly adorned.   I am a fairly picky eater, and despite some of the menu being quite "odd"  to my blaze palate, everything was superb!!  I will come back here in the future with a special someone, it is certainly the right atmosphere for romance.

AbTSVaVxl--hxxsNX-sa5w.text: Wish I wasn't sick on my visit here. I was struggling to figure out what was going on, but I didn't want to miss out on this opportunity and I'm glad I still came by.  I knew I wasn't going to finish the degustation menu, but I figured going for the 5 course would be sufficient.   My favorite was the black truffle spaghetti. It's like a $55 supplement, but damn...it was worth it. Nice rich sauce too.  And the bread and desserts are pretty damn good too. I would probably just come back, hang out in the lounge and just order dessert from their dessert cart.  If it wasn't for my sickness, I would have gone all out for the degustation menu. But I'll definitely be back to go for it in round two.

bb33VAKkJVaNiy9jmGjkPA.text: If there's a place worthy of splurging, like major "making benjamins rain (more like thunder shower!)" it would be here... and if you are independently wealthy, hit up Hakkasan both inside the MGM Grand.  (I did exactly that... but I starved for a few months... & I don't gamble... LOL).   From the moment we stepped in.. we were greeted by pleasantly the hostess and then the manager, walked us to our table.  The decor is a mix of glamour, heavy drapery, beautiful high ceiling and the table setting is fit for an upscale wedding.   I love how we were facing the outdoor garden and can see fresh greenery, a contrast to the dark drapery.  The lighting is perfect, not too bright but dim enough for awesome gram pics! The bathroom is hidden behind an enclosed pathway, it is a very beautified space for us ladies.    We chose the 12 course tasting menu... best decision ever because by course # 6... I was beyond full and almost about to bust out of my dress (unfortunate poor choice of wear... Vegas = Body hugging gear... ugh).  Each course is executed beautifully with creative plating and the sequence makes each bite mouth watering deliciousness.  Keep in mind, although it's 12 course, they throw in a few special "compliments from the chef", making your meal to be about 16 courses!    My favorite was the rib steak in cubes w/organic veggies, the artsy dessert in a spiral dome, the tasty lobster served like a wonton w/ pickled radish and both the "bread" & "dessert last bite" table! Delicious display of all kinds of bread on display with the smooth slow churned butter (my ultimate weakness!). The dessert table is beyond anyone's imagination & will give your "sweet tooth" a headache! Macarons!! Tarts!! Berries of all kind!! Cue: 50 Cents "I love you like a fat kid loves cake" on repeat while I tried to contain my excitement!   Definitely a YOLO moment for me!  Total bill... a little close to $1k... well, it's the Michelin Star way!  Would do it again! ;)   PS: they also give you a parting gift! Fresh made bread or cake more like! It was soft & yummy!   Happy "major splurging", YOLO Yelpers!

0CuAPGy-PtoAGM092hc8ng.text: This place is delicious and the service is amazing. We ordered the tasting menu. Each dish was well thought out and prepared perfectly. Every part of this experience was as it should be.

o5tOxXz3fI9Nit8EWeEXWA.text: Joel Robuchon is one of the best restaurants I have have been to. With drinks, dinner for two will cost you over $1000--but that price tag comes with three Michelin stars from one of the world's most celebrated chef. It is also one of the most expensive restaurants in North America.   The restaurant is small. It has an exclusive feel. The decor gives off an air of opulence - very fitting for a meal that will cost you over $1000.  A meal at Joel Robuchon is not simple meal. It is a 3+ production - a pageantry of culinary artistry. I should note that the production started well before we arrived at the restaurant. A limo was sent to our hotel to transport us to the MGM. We were then taken behind the MGM and guided to the restaurant.   The service was excellent. The servers were professional, attentive and friendly. I really enjoyed my interaction with all of the servers. They really enhanced my enjoyment of the evening.   We had the 18 course tasting menu. What can I say? The tasting menu was absolutely exquisite. It delighted all of the senses. Every course was a treat to the sense. I will highlight a few of my favourites:   (1) The La Langoustine with a truffled langostine ravioli with simmered green cabbage; La Noix de Saint-Jacques with a seared diver sea scallop served with kumquat and caviar; and La Soupe Folichonne with a medley of aromatic herbs in an exotic broth.  (2) L'Oursin, a sea urchin atop a puree of fennel and potato with citrus jus; Le Black Cod with caramelized black cod in a Malabar black pepper sauce with pak choy; and La Langouste, a spiny lobster grilled with a green curry jus and fresh coriander.   (4) The Le Caviar Imperial, a signature dish of Chef Robuchon's, which contain gold flakes.   (3) The Chateaubriand beef topped with foie gras and rolled in black truffles with a Porto sauce was delicious. Robuchon's famous puree de pomme de terre (Robuchon's famous mashed potatoes) comes with the dish. I must admit that I was quite full by this time.   Make sure you leave room for dessert. The dessert is just as good as all of the courses that came before and is a wonderful way to finish an epic dinner.

E0eCEfqYwuGq25OSIYlSoA.text: Located deep inside the MGM hotel, we walked, and walked, and walked until we finally found the restaurant. The hostess welcomed our party of four immediately and graciously offered to take some photos of the group before showing us to our table.   Touches of gold and crystal accessories give the posh dining room an air of surrealism, even for Las Vegas. Gem blues and purples set against a canvas of black and white set the stage for the grand performance. It took me several minutes to take it all in, and that's OK; I was having a moment as I looked around, while seated on a beautifully tufted purple settee.  It's a good thing I marveled at the decor for a bit; no one came to the table for a while which I thought was odd for this type of dinner. Finally, we requested to speak to the sommelier to get suggestions on French wine for our budget. When the somm came by, he replied that he had "just the right one and would bring it over." I found it odd he didn't offer various options, but decided to trust him and let it go. After a good ten minutes or so passed, we inquired as to his whereabouts with a gentleman who stood nearby. Sure enough, the somm finally reappeared carrying a bottle of wine which we tasted and approved. Minutes later, the gentleman that helped us with the somm came by to icily take our order. By now, I must admit I felt annoyed. High-end restaurants with dismissive attitudes are not OK in my book. Proper? Yes. Pompous. No! I don't care how highly awarded you are. It's not OK.   Thankfully, the rest of the staff and the waitress who then took over for the remainder of the night saved the day! She interacted perfectly by delivering a professional, yet casual experience.  She spoke with us at length explaining every dish, answering any questions we had, and sharing stories. Given we spent a good three hours or so there, this mattered greatly.    The food. Oh, the food. I, for one, loved it all and would return in a magical minute. Not everyone did, but I suppose they can get their own Yelp account and explain their side.   It's no secret this is an expensive restaurant. After all, Joel Robuchon is the most Michelin-starred chef IN THE WORLD. Naturally, before the Michelin Guide left Las Vegas, it had the very coveted three stars. As per my experience, it falls somewhere pricier than Eleven Madison (with a corkage fee) but less than Alinea/French Laundry (with wine pairings). The menu offers four options base priced at $127, $169, $198, or $250 pp. Basically, you combine a different number of appetizers, main courses, dessert, and mignardises. There are some supplementary charges as well. TIP: The $169 menu seemed to be the best option. No dessert needed. I thought it was odd they added the (usually complimentary) mignardises as an option, until I realized why. More on that in a bit. While the menu offered the expected classic French fare, the picturesque and tweezer-happy plating steered closer to French techniques of today.   WHAT I TRIED: Caviar & Salmon Tartar|Lobster & Guacamole|Truffled Langoustine Ravioli|Black Cod|Beef Ribeye|Plume of Iberico Pork|Souffle|Mignardises  HIGHLIGHT: The langoustine ravioli with its foie gras sauce, I wish I had a ten of those. We all agreed, this was a winner!  Every menu included an amuse bouche. Once we placed our orders, bread service began. Not just ANY bread service. A cart with at least a dozen in-house freshly baked bread of all types rolled up. TIP: While it's easy to over-order (is there such thing as too much bread?) start slowly, the bread comes around often throughout the night. Once you choose, the butter cart appears. Of course, it does. French butter sliced individually and olive oil poured tableside, such a treat.    The only dessert that appealed to me off the menu was the souffle. And while it actually delighted me- after all, it was perfect- I wish I would have saved the space for the grand finale: the mignardise cart. A stunning Wonka-esque display of sweets sat tableside, begging to be explored. I can't believe I'm admitting this, but I barely tried any. Darn souffle! It's probably my biggest regret of the night. Sigh. Because I happened to be celebrating my birthday, they also brought out a lovely and delicate complimentary meringue cake: adorned in spectacular pastel-colored rosettes and bearing a single candle. Happy birthday to me indeed! As a parting gift, every couple received a cellophane wrapped citrus butter loaf to take home, as a token of gratitude for visiting.   Despite the rocky start, dinner lived up to my (very high) expectations, and I dream of returning. If you are serious about fine dining and new experiences, add this one to your bucket list.   For my South Florida friends, know L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon (the more casual concept) should be opening Winter 2017 (reportedly, alongside Jean-Georges Vongerichten's ABC Kitchen and Bradley Kilgore's new restaurant). Gasp! Winter really IS coming!

N561q2WBf6tK1-_ITKFCzg.text: Fantastic! Here is my over due review of Joel Robuchon...  The meals and experiences here are always wonderful. The menu always changes with seasonal ingredients.    We started off with l'ceuf de poule - Hen's egg with caviar The next dish was Le Caviar Imperial  which was delicious! consisted of Scottish salmon confit coated with osetra caviar and a wasabi cream. I was pure treat paired with Vega-Sicilia Unico 1989. Silky with great power... Personally, the wine improves significantly over time. I suggest decanting and let it mix with oxygen.   The white asparagus with black garlic paste was delicious. The black garlic was very potent - the way I like my garlic... The black cod dish was one of my favorite and of course the Wagyu beef...  It was good way to end dinner with treats! on to the dessert cart. What a great evening.

LnEuc-Cb57RiUFbYIq-COA.text: Top 3 meals of my life!  Most celebrity chef's restaurants  in Vegas, I have found to be disappointing and they seem to have more sizzle than steak. Joel Robuchon is the exception! The attention to detail, the service, the food, the presentation...everything was just PERFECT.   Bernard Claeys, the General Manager gave me a little tour and told me about Joel Robuchon, the history of the restaurant and their system. He was great and if you watch him operate and see how he adjusts the silverware and greets the guest etc, you will know that he is a big reason why this restaurant is where it is.   The service was great. My party was dressed very casually compared to the other guests and the waiters and other staff still made us feel very comfortable. Paul who was our head waiter was awesome.   The food was incredible. Every dish was like a piece of art and the flavors were just bursting in my mouth.  And the bread, OMG! How do they make bread like this? With the hand churned butter and olive oil...delish. The chocolates for dessert and the pound cake were amazing. I am not a Vegas fan but I am going back just to dine here again!

inri0910jMdswNLVWvn50Q.text: This is simply the best of the best of the best, sir!!! I have been here 4 times and to the 1 star dozens of times sometimes twice in 1 week.  I have been to s few 3 stars and tons of 2 and 1 star restaurants.  I should of wrote this review years ago and I'm kicking myself because if I were to review every restaurant I have been to even just the upscale ones I would have hundreds if not thousands of reviews.  I eat out about 300 days a year.  Enough about me and let's get to the nuts and bolts of this review.  The ambiance and atmosphere is amazing, the dinning room is absolutely beautiful and very quiet.  I suggest wearing something purple to pop with the interior for your Instagram!  I always do the full 15 course menu to get a taste of everything and to enjoy the experience.  I will admit I had to skip a few courses the first time...  Now I am a seasoned vet and I can do the all the courses which I think they have taken a couple out over the years.  The bread cart may be the most impressive - a work of art and you want to eat so much... Hint - do not over load on bread!!!  You have 13-15 courses plus cheese cart and extra dessert cart after dessert courses!!! The sommelier is 2nd to none... He literally would talk a book about each wine.  He makes you want to drink wine and have him talk to you as you indulge and experience the essence in which it was created.  The courses are out of this world blending flavors and ingredients one could only be frightened by the complexity only to experience bliss with every bite!!!  The trios compress the time - give yourself 3 hours to dine here - at least 2 if in a hurry!!! Joel is a True master and there is no doubt to why he is the best of the best he best of the best.

iSgwmPevtZ363dpCR-4Lgg.text: Dined here a couple of months ago, let me begin with the arrival.  Thanks to many helpful Yelpers I called in advanced and reserved the gold limo pickup service.  Promptly at 7:30 they were in front of our hotel ready to pick my husband and I up.  When we arrived we entered through a back entrance where a beautifully dressed woman was waiting for us.  She then  escorted us all the way into the actual restaurant and our table. Wow, now that's an entrance.   The restaurant is not very large yet does not feel crowded in any way, instead it has a very intimate feeling.  There are beautiful chandeliers and rich fabrics everywhere.  Beautiful.We opted for the largest tasting menu.  Now we have had our share of tasting menus so we would like to think that for the most part we know pretty well what to expect, from the "flow" of the menu to the portions. Every dish here was so over the top, (in the best way  possible) oozing flavors.  One of my favorites was the "Caviar Surprise"  Ossetra  (also Oscietra, Osetra, Asetra) caviar served atop of king crab and a crustacean  gelee, yes I know!!!! Every dish was like this, rich and decadent.  By the time we reached the last course, the beef chop, we were stuffed.  This huge chop comes out of the kitchen and both my husband and I looked at each other , as in "that can't ALL be for us", and yes, yes it was.  Rich and buttery but we could only finish about a third of it.  Dessert was also delicious and at this point we were both tasting menu "wasted".  Were escorted back through the back of the hotel with cake to go, yes more food.  The gold limo dropped us off at our hotel where we proceeded to begin our food coma for the night.  Service, food, experience, all top notch.  M.P.
